Ban Kept for Gay Men Donating Blood 
 
 By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
 Published: May 23, 2007
 Filed at 4:02 p.m. ET
 
 WASHINGTON (AP) -- Gay men remain banned for life from donating blood, the government said Wednesday, leaving in place -- for now -- a 1983 prohibition meant to prevent the spread of HIV through transfusions.
 
 The Food and Drug Administration reiterated its long-standing policy on its Web site Wednesday, more than a year after the Red Cross and two other blood groups criticized the policy as ''medically and scientifically unwarranted.''
 
 ''I am disappointed, I must confess,'' said Dr. Celso Bianco, executive vice president of America's Blood Centers, whose members provide nearly half the nation's blood supply.
 
 Before giving blood, all men are asked if they have had sex, even once, with another man since 1977. Those who say they have are permanently banned from donating. The FDA said those men are at increased risk of infection by HIV that can be transmitted to others by blood transfusion.
 
 In March 2006, the Red Cross, the international blood association AABB and America's Blood Centers proposed replacing the lifetime ban with a one-year deferral following male-to-male sexual contact. New and improved tests, which can detect HIV-positive donors within just 10 to 21 days of infection, make the lifetime ban unnecessary, the blood groups told the FDA.
 
 In a document posted Wednesday, the FDA said it would change its policy if given data that show doing so wouldn't pose a ''significant and preventable'' risk to blood recipients.
 
 ''It is a way of saying, 'Whatever was presented to us was not sufficient to make us change our minds,''' Bianco said.
 
 The FDA said HIV tests currently in use are highly accurate, but still cannot detect the virus 100 percent of the time. The estimated HIV risk from a unit of blood is currently about one per 2 million in the United States, according to the agency.
 
 Critics of the exclusionary policy said it bars potential healthy donors, despite the increasing need for donated blood, and discriminates against gays. The FDA recognized the policy defers many healthy donors but rejected the suggestion it's discriminatory.
 
 Anyone who's used intravenous drugs or been paid for sex also is permanently barred from donating blood.

I'd say that anyone who is sexually highly active and not in a monogamous relationship shouldn't be donating blood, whether they are gay or straight. The issue for health authorities is that if someone is highly sexually active, then it's conceivable that they may give blood after recent infection owing to sexual activity, but before sufficient antibody or virus has developed to be detectable by tests. (And to be honest, even if you are monogamous, how can you be sure your partner is, too?)
 
 However, there doesn't seem to be a good health reason to ban people who haven't had sex for a few months, say a year to be safe, and who have no HIV antibodies or viral loads. If someone is public spirited enough to donate blood, why would they lie about their sexual activity on a private form that no-one else will see?
 
 I have, however, heard one argument about donation drives such as corporate ones, which is that people may feel pressured to give blood to avoid embarrassing questions from friends or co-workers about why they refused. They might feel inclined to understate their sexual activity or just plain lie about it.
 
 Still, blood donation organisations have this problem about people who might lie, anyway. There's nothing to stop some fearful and closeted gay person lying about whether they've had sex with a man, anyway, so I can't see the ban as being very effective protection against folk like that.
 
 In short, given that all donated blood is HIV tested anyway -- and it's HIV, folks, not AIDS -- what you really want to weed out are frequent fliers who might not have had enough time to become detectable. A blanket discrimination against gay men makes little sense any more, though it was perfectly understandable at the time it was initiated, which is why responsible gay men like me stopped donating. However, it's not reasonable to keep us from donating irrespective of our particular "lifestyles".

 The laboratory screening is done with an antibody based test. There is a "window" between the time one becomes infected and infectious and the time the HIV-antibody test becomes positive. There are antigen based tests (the so-called "viral load") that would detect the presence of HIV earlier but they are much more expensive and technically more difficult. When "screening" enormous quantities like this, the extra cost is not trivial and may be beyond the expertise of some labs. The questionnaire prior to giving blood is intended to reduce the probability of an infected person donating blood (in that window period) by screening out anyone at a risk for infection that is higher than some threshold.

 The criteria for screening is extensive. Questions specifically regarding HIV are 
 
 
HIV, AIDS
 You should not give blood if you have AIDS or have ever had a positive HIV test, or if you have done something that puts you at risk for becoming infected with HIV. 
 
 You are at risk for getting infected if you: 
 
 have ever used needles to take drugs, steroids, or anything not prescribed by your doctor 
 are a male who has had sexual contact with another male, even once, since 1977 
 have ever taken money, drugs or other payment for sex since 1977 
 have had sexual contact in the past 12 months with anyone described above 
 received clotting factor concentrates for a bleeding disorder such as hemophilia 
 were born in, or lived in, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Congo, Equatorial Guinea,Gabon, Niger, or Nigeria, since 1977. 
 since 1977, received a blood transfusion or medical treatment with a blood product in any of these countries, or 
 had sex with anyone who, since 1977, was born in or lived in any of these countries. Learn more about HIV Group O, and the specific African countries where it is found. 
 

 
 The screening criteria are intended to achieve an optimal sensitivity and specificity. What the goal is and whether these questions do that, I cannot say, but that is the essence of this argument. 
 
 Civil rights or sensibilities take a back seat to public health concerns. That is not to say that in the real world many of these decisions are not made with some political concern, but that should ideally never be considered.
